body.p: Stroke is a vascular disease and patients often have or are at risk of cardiovascular disorders. Cardiac rehabilitation programmes reduce vascular risk and might be appropriate for patients who have relatively minor strokes or transient ischaemic attacks. But do patients appreciate cardiac rehabilitation? A study within a randomised evaluative study suggests that patients are in favour. Returning home more quickly after hip arthroplasty is sometimes justified as being better for patients. They might not agree, but a comparative study here suggests that rates of satisfaction are not lower in units where patients stay three rather than six days. This study on patient evaluation of care and recovery also reports on a measure, and two other measures feature in this issue. One concerns clumsy children, where the properties of the ‘DCDDaily’ (Developmental Coordination Disorder; possibly a posh name for marked clumsiness) is evaluated. The other tackles a very difficult subject, measuring a person’s social networks. The measure – the Stroke Social Network Scale – could easily be used in any disorder because social networks are not unique to people with stroke! Hip arthroplasty is the subject of another interesting study that contrasted standard physiotherapy, which most people receive, with therapy tailored to the patients needs. It demonstrated quite significant benefits, as perhaps we should expect, but which is rarely investigated let alone shown to be the case. However group therapy is also advocated for several reasons (e.g cost, social support, peer advice) and an equally large study (n = 99) in people with multiple sclerosis showed significant benefits in comparison with no treatment. Another large (n = 60) study has investigated a space-age technology as treatment for people after stroke. Wearing a supportive elastic suit (the Regent Suit) seems to benefit recovery of mobility and other activities. Presumably increased sensory stimulation might be one mechanism. This theory underlies studies of using Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS) after stroke, and this journal has published several studies. This issue has another early phase study suggesting benefit in people late after stroke. Finally vibration therapy – another sensory stimulation – is studied as an adjunction to the use of botulinum toxin in treating spasticity, and it seems that using both leads to additional benefit.
